H0.text: Feathers are what birds, bats, and butterflies have in common.

H1.text: Hair is what birds, bats, and butterflies have in common.

H2.text: Internal skeleton is what birds, bats, and butterflies have in common.

H3.text: Wings are what birds, bats, and butterflies have in common.

A4.text: Bats are more agile in flight than most birds, flying with their long spread-out digits covered with a thin membrane or patagium.

A5.text: Terrestrial flightless birds have reduced wings or none at all (for example, moa).

A6.text: A wing injury is often crippling for flying birds, preventing them from feeding, socializing, or avoiding predators.

A7.text: A parent patrolling a nest will react to potential predators by vocalizing and presenting one or both wings at an extended angle, simulating a fracture; the predator therefore attempts to attack the healthy parent rather than continue foraging for the eggs or chicks.
